channel.title: Eclipse Plugins, Bundles and Products - Eclipse Marketplace

item.title: Sigasi Studio
item.description:
Date Created: 
Tue, 2009-05-19 09:35
Date Updated: 
Wed, 2017-09-27 05:40
Sigasi
Submitted by: 
Philippe Faes

Sigasi offers the leading plugin for VHDL and (System)Verilog

  • Makes standard editors obsolete
  • Type-time code analysis
  • Error reporting while you type
  • Smart content assist
  • Code inspection and navigation
  • Design hierarchy view (VHDL only)

Watch our 1 minute introduction video and review the feature list.

Sigasi Studio is an Intelligent Development Environment (IDE) for the VHDL and (System)Verilog languages. As other xDT plugins, such as JDT and CDT, it contains an ultra-fast parser and compiler that runs transparently in the background. At any given moment as you make modifications, the tool fully understands the design in terms of HDL concepts.

Sigasi Studio Starter

This plugin can be used free of charge on single files. If you want to try the full version, please request a trial license or buy a license on the Sigasi website.
item.dc:creator: pfaescce

item.title: Liferay IDE
item.description:
Date Created: 
Tue, 2010-06-15 17:56
Date Updated: 
Wed, 2017-09-27 02:43
Liferay, Inc
Submitted by: 
Greg Amerson

Liferay IDE provides Eclipse tooling for Liferay development platform for versions 6.2 and 7.0 including support for module development (OSGi) for Liferay Digital Enterprise 7.0 For more information on the latest release of the Liferay IDE see below: https://web.liferay.com/web/gregory.amerson/blog/-/blogs/liferay-ide-3-0... Also the main documentation and community information about the Liferay IDE is located on the following page: https://web.liferay.com/community/liferay-projects/liferay-ide/overview
item.dc:creator: gamersonokv

item.title: Contrast for Eclipse
item.description:
Date Created: 
Mon, 2014-08-25 18:21
Date Updated: 
Tue, 2017-09-26 14:36
Contrast Security
Submitted by: 
Harold McGinnis

Instrument your applications with Contrast Security to gain real-time visibility to vulnerabilities in your application, and to defend them against attacks. Contrast integrates with your existing SDLC processes to provide an easy way to view and fix vulnerabilities in your code, and protect your applications. The Contrast for Eclipse plugin lists the vulnerabilities from your application directly in your Eclipse environment enabling developers to resolve issues faster. Please note that you will need the Contrast TeamServer in order to use this feature. You can learn more about Contrast Security’s latest products by visiting our website at www.contrastsecurity.com . To schedule a demo, contact us at (https://www.contrastsecurity.com/demo) or by calling 1-888-371-1333 Welcome to the Era of Self-Protecting Software.
item.dc:creator: hmcginnis

item.title: cmake4eclipse
item.description:
Date Created: 
Fri, 2015-05-01 12:21
Date Updated: 
Tue, 2017-09-26 14:11
15knots
Submitted by: 
Martin Weber

This Eclipse plugin automatically generates build-scripts for the Eclipse CDT managed build system from CMake scripts. It allows to check out Eclipse C/C++ projects from SCM and instantly build them, without forcing You to perform manual preparation steps to make the build work.
For instructions inside the Eclipse workbench, go to Help:Help Contents, then open the 'CMake for CDT User Guide' node. See Why cmake4eclipse for details.

Browse project site
item.dc:creator: mweber0xe

Date Updated: 
Tue, 2017-09-26 08:24

This is a plugin offering a bit of minishift integration.

Currently it allows you to use a variable ${minishift_ip} which gets replaced with the current minishift IP address.

item.title: Cupid
item.description:
Date Created: 
Wed, 2015-11-11 22:56
Date Updated: 
Mon, 2017-09-25 10:50
NOAA Environmental Software Infrastructure and Interoperability
Submitted by: 
Rocky Dunlap

Cupid is a development and training environment for models that use the Earth System Modeling Framework (ESMF) and National Unified Operational Capability (NUOPC) Layer infrastructure. Key features:

  • Analyze models coupled with NUOPC and create an outline of the model architecture 
  • Show the components in the application, their initialize, run, and finalize phases, and their NUOPC compliance status
  • Present the outline side-by-side with code editor
  • Provide contextual guidance to the developer while NUOPC code is being edited
  • Generate code needed for NUOPC compliance automatically
item.dc:creator: rdunlapmqd

item.title: Preference Editor
item.description:
Date Created: 
Thu, 2017-07-06 10:13
Date Updated: 
Mon, 2017-09-25 07:45
OnPositive
Submitted by: 
Dmitry Karpenko

Preference Editor

Eclipse Preference Editor would be useful for developers debugging Eclipse/RCP applications - it allows to view/edit preferences for the running IDE, as well as for some workspace, configuration area, debugged configuration area or some arbitrary folder.


"Folder"/"Offline" editing

This mode allows changing preferences by editing special files containing them prior to launching particular IDE or workspace, changes are saved to corresponding files immediately.


"Platform"/"Online" editing

"Online" editing allows you to edit preferences from currently running platform/IDE.

Since 1.3, plugin can listen to preference changes for both current platform and folder modes. Alternatively, tracking can be turned off, please use "reload" button to refresh view content in such case.
item.dc:creator: dkarpenko

item.title: Design and Verification Tools (DVT) IDE for e, SystemVerilog, and VHDL
item.description:
Date Created: 
Wed, 2006-04-19 08:00
Date Updated: 
Mon, 2017-09-25 06:56
AMIQ EDA
Submitted by: 
AMIQ Support

Design and Verification Tools (DVT) is an integrated development environment (IDE) for the e language, SystemVerilog, Verilog, VHDL, and mixed language projects that also provides Universal Verification Methodology (UVM) support. It is similar to well-known programming tools like Visual Studio®, NetBeans®, and IntelliJ®. DVT comprises a proprietary IEEE standard-compliant parser, a smart code editor, an intuitive GUI, a comprehensive set of features that help with code inspection, navigation, documentation, and debugging, and an innovative linting framework. DVT allows design and verification engineers to overcome the limitations of plain text editors and use a modern and powerful tool that enables them to:

  • Increase the speed and quality of new code development
  • Easily understand complex or poorly documented source code
  • Simplify the maintenance of legacy code and reusable libraries
  • Accelerate language and methodology learning
  • Automatically generate well-organized source code documentation

FEATURES Some of the features that DVT offers include:

  • Autocomplete
  • Compilation errors signaled on the fly
  • In-line reminders for task tracking (TO DOs)
  • Customizable code and project templates
  • Dedicated wizards to generate getters and setters, override functions, or help with UVM factory registration
  • Hyperlinks that help navigate faster in the source code
  • Semantic search
  • Refactoring
  • Macro expansion
  • Class and structural browsing
  • Trace port connections
  • UML diagrams for inspecting and documenting the architecture
  • Module flow diagrams for inspecting and documenting a module structure
  • Automated documentation extraction
  • UVM support and compliance checking
  • Cross-language capabilities for mixed-language projects
  • Vi and emacs emulation

INTEGRATION WITH OTHER TOOLS Since it is built on the Eclipse Platform, the DVT IDE can be easily integrated within a large plug-in ecosystem. It also integrates seamlessly with all major hardware simulators such as NCSim , Specman , VCS , and Questa, to enable simplified simulation analysis and debugging. In addition, it works with revision control systems like CVS, Git, Subversion, ClearCase and bug tracking systems such as Bugzilla and ClearQuest.
RESOURCES

  • DVT web page
  • DVT datasheet
  • Demo movies
  • UVM Support in DVT
  • DVT Debugger Module
item.dc:creator: emisingname6ia

item.title: Java 9 Support for Oxygen
item.description:
Date Created: 
Tue, 2015-06-16 11:11
Date Updated: 
Mon, 2017-09-25 05:25
The Eclipse Foundation
Submitted by: 
Wayne Beaton

Java™ 9 support for Eclipse JDT is available now. Full Java ™ 9 support for the Oxygen simultaneous release will come with Oxygen 1a to be released on October 11.

You can add the support to your existing Eclipse Oxygen (4.7) install. The Eclipse Java™ 9 support contains the following:

  • ability to add JRE and JDK 9 as installed JRE
  • support for JavaSE-9 execution environment
  • ability to create Java and Plug-in projects that use a JRE or JDK 9
  • ability to compile modules that are part of a Java project
  • Checkout https://wiki.eclipse.org/Java9/Examples for some working examples of Java 9 features.

Pre-requisite:

  • You need Oxygen (4.7 or above)  Eclipse SDK or maintenance(M) builds (available from http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/)
  • The Java™ 9 support also works when the IDE is launched with a Java™ 8 VM. There is no need to switch Java™ 9 VM for that.
  • For any Eclipse install <= Oxygen 1 you have to add --add-modules=ALL-SYSTEM. For more details and potential issues see https://wiki.eclipse.org/Configure_Eclipse_for_Java_9.
  • You need Java™ 9 JDK ( Available from the JDK9 pointer at the parent site: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html)

To try out Java 9 support in Eclipse, you can follow any of these:

  • Update your Eclipse 4.7 build using this update site: http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/updates/4.7-U-builds. In Eclipse, go to Help > Install New Software... and uncheck "Group items by category". Select "Eclipse SDK" from the list of items and proceed with the installation.
  • Update your Eclipse 4.7 build for committers (https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/eclipse-ide-eclipse-committer...) using Eclipse Marketplace entry (currently, needs some additional steps):
  1. Drag and drop the Install button on this web page to your running Eclipse workspace. This will open the Eclipse Marketplace dialog.
  2. Click the link "One solution selected" at the bottom.
  3. In the Java 9 support entry, press "Update Pending" button.
  4. Press the same button again, now named "Update". Ignore the progress bar message at the bottom.
  5. On the next page which comes up, make sure "Update my installation..." is selected and press "Confirm".
  6. Accept the license and proceed with the installation.

Please note that this update is not intended for (4.8) Photon's builds (integration/milestone) - but is intended for Oxygen builds.

Note:

  • If you are using the update site or the marketplace entry with an Eclipse 4.7 M-build, make sure that the latest available U-build on http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/updates/4.7-U-builds/?d (fetched by the update site and marketplace entry) was built after your M-build.
  • Note that this update also contains JUnit 5 support. For details see https://marketplace.eclipse.org/content/junit-5-support-oxygen.
item.dc:creator: wbeaton
